src: 內容理論的核心，是找出讓人心動或吸引他們的東西。 這些理論認為人們有一些需求或渴望，在長大成人的過程中內化了。 這些理論探討是什麼讓某些人想要某些東西，以及在他們的環境中，是什麼讓他們想做或不做某些事。 馬斯洛的需求層次理論和赫茲伯格的雙因子理論，是兩個熱門的內容理論。
mt: The core of content theories is to find out what moves people or attracts them. These theories assume that people have some needs or desires that are internalized in the process of growing up. These theories discuss what makes some people want some things and what in their environment makes them want to do or not do some things. Maslow's hierarchy of needs and Herzberg's two-factor theory are two popular content theories.
ref: Content theories are centered on finding what makes people tick or appeals to them. These theories suggest that people have certain needs and/or desires which have been internalized as they mature to adulthood. These theories look at what it is about certain people that make them want the things that they do and what things in their environment will make them do or not do certain things. Two popular content theories are Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs Theory and Hertzberg's Two Factor Theory.

src: 常被濫用和嘲笑的三分法是種簡單的指導方針，在創造活力的同時，也使畫面保持井然有序。 它指出將圖像垂直和水平三等分後，線條的交點便是拍攝主體最有效的位置（見範例）。
mt: 3:1 Rule is a simple guideline that is often abused and mocked. It points out that the intersection of the lines created by dividing the image vertically and horizontally into thirds is the most effective position to place the subject (see example).
ref: The much-abused and often-ridiculed rule of thirds is a simple guideline creating dynamism while keeping a measure of order in an image. It states that the most effective place for the main subject is at the intersection of lines dividing the image into thirds vertically and horizontally (see example).

src: 舉例來說，世界上最普遍的靜態圖像攝影格式是 35 釐米，這也是類比底片時代結束時的主要底片尺寸。 它至今日仍持續在生產，不過更重要的是，數位相機的感光元件規格沿用了其長寬比。 事實上，那 35 公釐的格式有些令人困惑，寬 36 公釐，高 24 公釐。 此格式的長寬比（除以 12，以獲得最簡單整數比）因此稱為 3:2。 許多常見格式（比方 APS 先進攝影系統格式）都等同或接近這個長寬比。
mt: 35mm is the most common static image photography format, and it is the main film size at the end of the analog era. It is still produced today, but more importantly, the digital camera sensor specifications follow its aspect ratio. In fact, that 35mm format is a bit confusing, 36mm wide, 24mm high. The format's aspect ratio (divided by 12, to get the simplest integer ratio) is therefore called 3:2. Many common formats (such as APS Advanced Photo System) are equivalent or close to this aspect ratio.
ref: For example, the most common still image photography format in the world is 35mm, which was the dominant film size at the close of the analog film era. It is still produced today, but more importantly its aspect ratio has been inherited by digital camera image sensor formats. The 35mm format is actually, somewhat confusingly, 36mm in width by 24mm in height. The aspect ratio of this format (dividing by twelve to obtain the simplest whole-number ratio) is therefore said to be 3:2. Many common formats (APS family of formats, for example) are equal to or closely approximate this aspect ratio.

src: 變焦鏡頭的缺點是，達到一定焦距範圍所需的焦點複雜度和鏡片元件數量，遠大於定焦鏡頭。 隨著鏡片製造商的鏡片生產達到更高水準，這已不再成為問題。 這已能使變焦鏡頭拍出與定焦鏡頭不相上下的照片品質。 變焦鏡頭的另一缺點是鏡頭的最大光圈（速度）通常較低。 這就使得平價的變焦鏡頭在低光源、無閃光燈的環境中難以使用。
mt: The main disadvantage of zoom lenses is that the focusing complexity and number of lens elements required to achieve a given zoom range is much greater than for a fixed focal length lens. As lens manufacturers have improved their lens production, this is no longer a problem. This can allow zoom lenses to produce image quality comparable to fixed focal length lenses. Another disadvantage of zoom lenses is that the maximum aperture (f-number) is usually lower. This makes low cost zoom lenses difficult to use in low light, without flash.
ref: The disadvantage of zoom lenses is that the focal complexity and number of lens elements required to achieve a range of focal lengths is much greater than for prime lenses. This is becoming less of an issue as lens manufacturers achieve higher standards in lens production. This has allowed zoom lenses to produce pictures of a quality comparable to that achieved by lenses with fixed focal length. Another disadvantage of zoom lenses is that the maximum aperture (the speed) of the lens is usually lower. This makes inexpensive zoom lenses hard to use in low-light conditions without a flash.

src: 神祕主義是追求與終極現實、神性、屬靈的真理、或神之間的交流、認同、或意識覺醒。 信仰者尋求對神性實相 / 神或眾神的直接體驗、直觀或洞悉。 跟隨者尋求旨在滋養這些體驗的特定生活或修行方式。 神祕主義與其它宗教信仰與崇拜能有所分別，是因為它看重個人對於一種獨特意識狀態的直接經驗，尤其是那種平和、洞察、喜悅、甚至是狂喜的特質。
mt: The term "mysticism" refers to the pursuit and/or attainment of direct experience of the ultimate reality, divinity, spiritual truth, or God. Believers seek direct experience of the divine reality/God or the gods. Followers seek specific ways of life or practices that are intended to nurture these experiences. Mysticism can be distinguished from other religious beliefs and practices because it emphasizes the direct experience of a particular state of consciousness, especially one characterized by peace, insight, joy, and even ecstasy.
ref: Mysticism is the pursuit of communion with, identity with, or conscious awareness of an ultimate reality, divinity, spiritual truth, or God. The believer seeks a direct experience, intuition, or insight into divine reality/the deity or dieties. Followers pursue certain ways of living, or practices that are intended to nurture those experiences. Mysticism can be distinguished from other forms of religious belief and worship by its emphasis on the direct personal experience of a unique state of consciousness, particularly those of a peaceful, insightful, blissful, or even ecstatic character.

src: 十九到二十世紀的很長一段時間，人們都相信紐西蘭的第一批居民是毛利人，他們會獵捕稱為恐鳥的巨鳥。 該理論隨後確立一個觀點，認為毛利人乘坐大艦隊，自玻里尼西亞開始遷徙，然後從莫里奧里人手中奪取紐西蘭，並建立一個農業社會。 然而，新的證據指出，莫里奧里人是一個紐西蘭大陸的毛利人族群，他們從紐西蘭遷徙到查塔姆群島，發展出了自己獨特的和平文化。 查塔姆群島上還有另一個部落，他們是從紐西蘭移民而來的毛利人。 它們稱自己為莫里奧里人，之前發生了一些小衝突，而最終莫里奧里人被抹消了。
mt: 19th and 20th centuries, people believe that the first inhabitants of New Zealand are Maori, they will hunt the giant birds called moa. The theory was later established a view that Maori boarded a fleet of ships, began to migrate from Polynesia, and then from the Moriori people of New Zealand, and established an agricultural society. However, new evidence shows that the Moriori is a Maori group of New Zealand mainland, they migrated to the Chatham Islands, and developed their own unique peaceful culture. There is another tribe on the Chatham Islands, they are from New Zealand immigrants Maori. They call themselves Moriori, and there have been some minor conflicts, and eventually the Moriori was wiped out.
ref: For a long time during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, it was believed the first inhabitants of New Zealand were the Maori people, who hunted giant birds called moas. The theory then established the idea that the Maori people migrated from Polynesia in a Great Fleet and took New Zealand from the Moriori, establishing an agricultural society. However, new evidence suggests that the Moriori were a group of mainland Maori who migrated from New Zealand to the Chatham Islands, developing their own distinctive, peaceful culture. There was also another tribe on the Chatham islands these were Maori who migrated away from New Zealand. They called themselves the Moriori there were a few skirmishes and in the end, the Moriori were wiped out

src: 我們將永遠無法擺脫貪婪與自私。合作的本質就是當大多數人受益時，自私的行為在短期總能得到更多利益。 希望多數人終將明白他們長期的最佳選擇是與他人合作。
mt: We will never be able to get rid of greed and selfishness. The essence of cooperation is that when most people benefit, selfish behavior can get more benefits in the short term. I hope that most people will eventually realize that their long-term best choice is to cooperate.
ref: Greed and selfishness will always be with us and it is the nature of cooperation that when the majority benefit there will always be more to gain in the short term by acting selfishly Hopefully, most people will realise that their long term best option is to work together with others.

src: 美國帝國主義征戰菲律賓的戰爭支出則由菲律賓人民自身繳納。 他們被迫繳稅給美國殖民政權，支付大部分的政府開支，而債券利息則以菲律賓政府的名義透過華爾街銀行浮動。 當然，美國長久以來剝削菲律賓人取得的超高利潤，成為美國帝國主義的基本收穫。
mt: The cost of the American imperialist war against the Philippines was borne by the Filipino people themselves. They were forced to pay taxes to the American colonial government, paying for most of the government expenses, and the interest on the bonds was floated through Wall Street banks in the name of the Philippine government. Of course, the super profits that the Americans have long been exploiting the Filipino people have become the basic harvest of American imperialism.
ref: The war expenditures of U.S. imperialism in the conquest of the Philippines were paid for by the Filipino people themselves. They were compelled to pay taxes to the U.S. colonial regime to defray a major part of the expenditures and the interest on bonds floated in the name of the Philippine government through the Wall Street banking houses. Of course, the superprofits derived from the protracted exploitation of the Filipino people would constitute the basic gains of U.S. imperialism.

src: 若要了解聖殿騎士團，就必須了解促使這個組織創立的脈絡。 通常把這些事件發生的時代稱為中古盛期，也就是歐洲歷史的 11、12 和 13 世紀（西元 1000–1300 年）。 中世紀中期前承中世紀前期、後接中世紀後期，而傳統上認為中世紀結束於 1500 年左右。
mt: To understand the Knights Templar, one must understand the context in which the organization was founded. This period is usually referred to as the High Middle Ages, or the 11th, 12th, and 13th centuries (1000–1300 AD). The High Middle Ages preceded the Early Middle Ages and followed the Late Middle Ages, and the Middle Ages are traditionally considered to have ended around 1500 AD.
ref: To understand the Templars one must understand the context that prompted the creation of the order. The age where the events took place is commonly referred as the High Middle Ages the period of European history in the 11th, 12th, and 13th centuries (AD 1000–1300). The High Middle Ages were preceded by the Early Middle Ages and followed by the Late Middle Ages, which by convention ends around 1500.

src: 羅馬帝國軍國主義的本質，有助於醫學進步的發展。 奧古斯都皇帝開始招募醫生，這些醫生甚至成立了第一支用於戰後時期的羅馬醫療隊。 醫生已經知道許多種鎮定劑的存在了，包括從罌粟花籽中提煉出的嗎啡和莨菪籽中的莨菪鹼。 他們精通截肢術，將患者從壞疽與因止血帶和動脈夾鉗阻止血液流動所造成的傷害中拯救出來。 數世紀以來，羅馬帝國在醫學領域的研究成果豐碩，奠定現今許多醫學知識的基礎。
mt: 1. The essence of Roman imperialism helped medical progress. Emperor Augustus began recruiting physicians, who even formed the first Roman medical corps after the war. Physicians already knew of many sedatives, including morphine extracted from poppy seeds and atropine extracted from henbane seeds. They were skilled in amputation, rescuing patients from gangrene and injuries caused by tourniquets and artery clamps that prevented blood flow. For centuries, Roman Empire's research achievements in the medical field were abundant, laying the foundation for many medical knowledge today.
ref: The militaristic nature of the Roman empire aided in the development of medical advances. Doctors began to be recruited by Emperor Augustus and even formed the first Roman Medical Corps for use in the aftermath of battles. Surgeons had knowledge of various sedatives including morphine from extracts of poppy seeds and scopolamine from herbane seeds. They became proficient at amputation to save patients from gangrene as well as tourniquets and arterial clamps to stem blood flow. Over multiple centuries, the Roman empire led to great gains in the field of medicine and formed much of the knowledge we know today.

src: 視力，或視物的能力，來自視覺系統的感覺器官或眼睛。 眼睛包含許多不同構造，各構造的複雜度依其對有機體需求不同而有差別。 不同的結構有不同的功能、對不同的波長敏感、具有不同的敏銳度，還需要不同的處理過程來理解輸入，以及不同的數量達到最佳效率。
mt: Vision, or the ability to see, comes from the sensory organs or eyes. The eyes contain many different structures, each with varying complexity depending on their need to the organism. Different structures have different functions, are sensitive to different wavelengths, have different sensitivities, and require different processing to understand the input, and different quantities to achieve optimal efficiency.
ref: Vision, or the ability to see depends on visual system sensory organs or eyes. There are many different constructions of eyes, ranging in complexity depending on the requirements of the organism. The different constructions have different capabilities, are sensitive to different wave-lengths and have differing degrees of acuity, also they require different processing to make sense of the input and different numbers to work optimally.

src: 錫克教是源自印度次大陸的宗教。其起源為 15 世紀旁遮普地區自印度教傳統中分裂出來的派別。 雖然他們承認來自印度教的根源與傳統，但錫克教徒認為自身的信仰不同於印度教。 錫克教徒將他們的信仰稱為古馬特 (Gurmat)，在旁遮普語中意指「上師之道」。上師是所有印度信仰的基礎，但在錫克教裡，上師構成了整個信仰的重要核心。 此宗教是由古魯那奈克（1469–1539）於 15 世紀所創立。在他之後又依序出現了九位大師。
mt: Sikhism is a religion that originated in the Indian subcontinent as a separate identity from Hinduism in the 15th century. Although they recognize the roots and traditions of Hinduism, Sikhs believe their faith is distinct from Hinduism. Sikhs call their faith Gurmat, meaning "the way of the Guru" in Punjabi. The Guru is the basis of all Indian faiths, but in Sikhism the Guru is an important core of the entire faith. This religion was founded by Guru Nanak (1469–1539) in the 15th century, followed by nine subsequent Gurus.
ref: "Sikhism is a religion from the Indian sub-continent. It originated in the Punjab region during the 15th century from a sectarian split within the Hindu tradition. Sikhs consider their faith to be a separate religion from Hinduism though they acknowledge its Hindu roots and traditions. Sikhs call their religion Gurmat, which is Punjabi for ""way of the guru"". The guru is a fundamental aspect of all Indian religions but in Sikhism has taken on an importance that forms the core of Sikh beliefs. The religion was founded in the 15th century by Guru Nanak (1469–1539). There followed in succession a further nine gurus."

src: 注意力缺失症「是一種神經性綜合症狀，其典型的三種症狀包含衝動、分心、過動或精力過剩。」 它並非學習障礙，而是學習疾患；「有 3-5 % 的兒童受其影響，大概等同於 2 百萬的美國兒童」。 患有注意力缺失症的兒童，很難專注於學校作業之類的事物，但他們能專心做自己有興趣的事情，比方玩遊戲或觀賞他們喜歡的卡通，或書寫文句但不加標點符號。 這些孩子容易惹上很多麻煩，因為他們不能用尋常的方法刺激大腦，要「做出危險的行為、牽扯進打架並挑戰權威」才能刺激大腦。 注意力缺乏症影響與其他同儕的關係，因為其他孩子不能理解他們為何會有這種作為，或是他們為何會這樣拼音，或是他們的成熟度不同。
mt: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neurobiological disorder characterized by three main symptoms: impulsivity, inattention, and hyperactivity or excess energy. It is not a learning disability, but a learning disorder; 3-5 percent of children are affected, which is roughly equivalent to 2 million American children. Children with ADHD have difficulty focusing on schoolwork and other tasks, but can focus on things they are interested in, such as playing games or watching their favorite cartoons, or writing sentences without punctuation. These children are prone to getting into trouble because they cannot stimulate their brains in the usual way, and must "act out, get into fights, and challenge authority" to stimulate their brains. ADHD affects relationships with peers because other children cannot understand why they behave this way, or why they spell words this way, or why they are less mature.
ref: "Attention Deficit Disorder ""is a neurological syndrome whose classic defining triad of symptoms including impulsivity, distractibility, and hyperactivity or excess energy"". It is not a learning disability, it is a learning disorder; it ""affects 3 to 5 percent of all children, perhaps as many as 2 million American children"". Children with ADD have a hard time focusing on things like school work, but they can concentrate on things they enjoy doing like playing games or watching their favorite cartoons or writing sentences without punctuation. These children tend to get into a lot of trouble, because they ""engage in risky behaviors, get into fights, and challenge authority"" in order to stimulate their brain, since their brain can not be stimulated by normal methods. ADD affects relationships with other peers because other children can not understand why they act the way that they do or why they spell they way they do or that their maturity level is different."

src: 注意力缺失症「是一種神經性綜合症狀，其典型的三種症狀包含衝動、分心、過動或精力過剩。」 它並非學習障礙，而是學習疾患；「有 3-5 % 的兒童受其影響，大概等同於 2 百萬的美國兒童」。 患有注意力缺失症的兒童，很難專注於學校作業之類的事物，但他們能專心做自己有興趣的事情，比方玩遊戲或觀賞他們喜歡的卡通，或書寫文句但不加標點符號。 這些孩子容易惹上很多麻煩，因為他們不能用尋常的方法刺激大腦，要「做出危險的行為、牽扯進打架並挑戰權威」才能刺激大腦。 注意力缺乏症影響與其他同儕的關係，因為其他孩子不能理解他們為何會有這種作為，或是他們為何會這樣拼音，或是他們的成熟度不同。
mt: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neurobiological disorder characterized by three main symptoms: impulsivity, inattention, and hyperactivity or excess energy. It is not a learning disability, but a learning disorder; 3-5 percent of children are affected, which is roughly equivalent to 2 million American children. Children with ADHD have difficulty focusing on schoolwork and other tasks, but can focus on things they are interested in, such as playing games or watching their favorite cartoons, or writing sentences without punctuation. These children are prone to getting into trouble because they cannot stimulate their brains in the usual way, and must "act out, get into fights, and challenge authority" to stimulate their brains. ADHD affects relationships with peers because other children cannot understand why they behave this way, or why they spell words this way, or why they are less mature.
ref: "Attention Deficit Disorder ""is a neurological syndrome whose classic defining triad of symptoms including impulsivity, distractibility, and hyperactivity or excess energy"". It is not a learning disability, it is a learning disorder; it ""affects 3 to 5 percent of all children, perhaps as many as 2 million American children"". Children with ADD have a hard time focusing on things like school work, but they can concentrate on things they enjoy doing like playing games or watching their favorite cartoons or writing sentences without punctuation. These children tend to get into a lot of trouble, because they ""engage in risky behaviors, get into fights, and challenge authority"" in order to stimulate their brain, since their brain can not be stimulated by normal methods. ADD affects relationships with other peers because other children can not understand why they act the way that they do or why they spell they way they do or that their maturity level is different."

src: 以專案為基礎的學習方式讓學習更容易也更有趣，鷹架式學習則又更上一層樓。 鷹架式教學並非學習方法，而是一種輔助，可為正在經歷新學習體驗（如使用新電腦程式或開始新專案等）的人提供支援。 鷹架既可虛擬也可實體，換句話說，教師和 Microsoft Office 的迴紋針小幫手都是一種鷹架的型態。 虛擬鷹架已內建在軟體中，功能是提問、提示和說明學生可能難以獨自處理的程序。
mt: Project-based learning makes learning easier and more fun, scaffolding takes it to the next level. Scaffolding is not a learning method, but a support that can be provided to people who are new to a learning experience (such as using a new computer program or starting a new project). Scaffolding can be virtual or physical, meaning that teachers and Microsoft Office's little help icons are both types of scaffolding. Virtual scaffolding is built into the software, and its function is to ask questions, prompt, and explain procedures that students may be unable to handle on their own.
ref: While project based learning should make learning easier and more interesting, scaffolding goes a step beyond. Scaffolding is not a method of learning but rather an aid that provides support to individuals whom are undergoing a new learning experience such as using a new computer program or beginning a new project. Scaffolds can be both virtual and real, in other words, a teacher is a form of scaffold but so is the little paperclip man in Microsoft Office. Virtual Scaffolds are internalized in the software and are meant to question, prompt, and explain procedures that may have been to challenging for the student to handle alone.

src: MySpace 是美國排名第三受使用者歡迎的網站，目前有 5 千 4 百萬個帳戶。 這些網站獲得了很多關注，尤其是在教育領域方面。 這些網站的優點包含能輕鬆建立班級頁面，涵蓋了部落格、影片、照片與其他功能。 只要提供一個網址就可以輕易開啟這個網頁，這對在使用鍵盤或拼字上有困難的學生來說，更容易記憶與輸入。 您可自訂頁面，使之易於閱讀：亦可根據喜好，使用大量或少量顏色。
mt: MySpace is the third most popular website in the United States, with 54 million accounts. These websites have received a lot of attention, especially in the educational field. These websites have advantages such as being easy to create class pages, covering blogs, videos, photos, and other functions. Just provide a URL to easily open this page, which is easier to remember and input for students who have difficulty using the keyboard or spelling. You can customize the page to be easy to read: you can use a lot or a little color according to your preferences.
ref: MySpace is the third most popular website used in the United States and has 54 million profiles currently. These websites have gotten a lot of attention, especially in the education setting. There are positive aspects to these websites, which include, being able to easily setup a class page which can include blogs, videos, photos, and other features. This page can easily be accessed by providing just one web address, which makes it easy to remember and easy to type in for students who may have trouble using the keyboard or with spelling. It can be customized to make it easy to read and also with as much or little color as desired.

src: 不過，1956 年 6 月時，波蘭的工人為食物短缺和減薪進行抗議，卻轉變成對共產主義的普遍抗議，這些動亂讓赫魯雪夫的承諾受到考驗。 雖然赫魯雪夫最後派出坦克來恢復秩序，但他還是在某些經濟要求上做出讓步，並同意任命受到愛戴的瓦迪斯瓦夫·哥穆爾卡擔任新總理。
mt: 1956, however, saw workers in Poland protest food shortages and wage cuts, but the demonstrations turned into a general protest against communism. The unrest tested Gromyko's promises. Although Gromyko eventually sent in tanks to restore order, he did make some economic concessions and agreed to appoint the popular Wladyslaw Gomulka as the new prime minister.
ref: However, in June 1956, Krushchev's promises were put to the test when riots in Poland, where workers were protesting against food shortages and wage cuts, turned into a general protest against Communism. Although in the end, Krushchev sent in tanks to restore order, he did give way to some economic demands and agreed to appoint the popular Wladyslaw Gomulka as the new prime minister.

src: 德國是二戰時期的共同敵人，促使蘇聯與美國合作。隨著戰爭結束，制度、做法和文化方面的衝突使這些國家有了嫌隙。 二戰結束不過兩年，原本的盟友就成了敵人，冷戰開始。 它接連持續了四十年，並由代理軍隊在從非洲到亞洲，在阿富汗﹑古巴和許多其他地方的戰場上進行真正的戰鬥。
mt: Germany was a common enemy during World War II, prompting the Soviet Union and the United States to cooperate. As the war ended, conflicts in systems, practices and cultures led to these countries having a grudge. The war ended only two years ago, and the former allies became enemies, the Cold War began. It continued for forty years, and proxy armies fought real battles on battlefields from Africa to Asia, in Afghanistan, Cuba, and many other places.
ref: Germany was a common enemy in World War 2, leading to cooperation between the USSR and USA. With the end of the war the clashes of system, process and culture led to the countries falling out. With two years of the end of the war, the former allies were now enemies and the Cold War began. It was to last for the next 40 years and would be fought for real, by proxy armies, on battlefields from Africa to Asia, in Afghanistan, Cuba and many other places.

src: 神經系統藉由發送神經衝動到全身，保持血液流動且不受干擾，進而維持體內恆定。 這些神經脈衝以極快的速度傳送到身體各處，協助身體避開潛在威脅。
mt: The nervous system maintains homeostasis by sending nerve impulses throughout the body, keeping blood flowing and unimpeded, and maintaining the body's constant state. These nerve impulses are sent at extremely fast speeds to all parts of the body, helping the body avoid potential threats.
ref: The Nervous System maintains homeostasis by sending nerve impulses through out the body to keep the flow of blood going as well as undisturbed. These nerve impulses can be sent so quickly throughout the body which helps keep the body safe from any potential threat.

src: 吉薩大金字塔是現今唯一仍矗立的世界七大奇蹟。 大金字塔在公元前三世紀由埃及人建造而成，它是建來紀念已故法老的眾多大型金字塔建築物之一。 位於埃及亡者谷的吉薩高原或「吉薩金字塔群」，包含好幾座金字塔（其中大金字塔是世界上最大的金字塔）、幾座小陵墓、幾座神廟和巨大的獅身人面像。 大金字塔是為了榮耀古夫法老所建造的，而許多較小的金字塔、陵墓和神廟則是為了榮耀古夫的妻妾和家庭成員而建。
mt: The Great Pyramid of Giza is the only one of the original Seven Wonders of the World still standing. The Great Pyramid was built by the Egyptians around 2500 BC to honor the dead Pharaoh. The Great Pyramid is part of the Giza Necropolis, which also includes several smaller pyramids, tombs, and a giant statue of a lion with a human head. The Great Pyramid was built to honor the Pharaoh, and many smaller pyramids, tombs, and temples were built to honor the Pharaoh's wives and family members.
ref: "The Great Pyramid at Giza is the only one of the seven wonders that is still standing today. Built by the Egyptians in the third century BCE, the Great Pyramid is one of many large pyramid structures built to honor dead Pharaoh. The Giza Plateau, or ""Giza Necropolis"" in the Egyptian Valley of the Dead contains several pyramids (of which the great pyramid is the largest), several small tombs, several temples, and the great Sphinx. The great pyramid was created to honor the Pharaoh Khufu, and many of the smaller pyramids, tombs, and temples were built to honor Khufu's wives and family members."

src: 位於艾費蘇斯的阿緹密絲神殿於西元前 356 年 7 月 21 日，因黑若史達特斯蓄意縱火而燒毀。 從故事可知，他的動機來自不計代價獲取聲望。憤怒的以弗所人宣告黑若斯達特斯之名永遠都不會載入史冊。 希臘歷史學家史特拉波後來提到了這個名字，所以我們現在才會知道有這座神殿。神殿毀於亞歷山大大帝出生當晚。 亞歷山大作為國王主動提議出資重建神廟，但他的提議遭到否決。亞歷山大死後，神廟才於公元前 323 年被重建起來。
mt: The Temple of Artemis at Ephesus was destroyed by fire on July 21, 356 BC, by Erostratus. From the story, we know that his motive was to gain fame at any cost. The Ephesians declared that the name of Erostratus would never be recorded in history. The Greek historian Strabo later mentioned this name, so we now know that the temple existed. The temple was destroyed on the night of Alexander the Great's birth. Alexander, as king, voluntarily offered to pay for the reconstruction of the temple, but his offer was rejected. The temple was not rebuilt until after Alexander's death in 323 BC.
ref: The temple of Artemis at Ephesus was destroyed on July 21, 356 BCE in an act of arson committed by Herostratus. According to the story, his motivation was fame at any cost. The Ephesians, outraged, announced that Herostratus' name never be recorded. The Greek historian Strabo later noted the name, which is how we know today. The temple was destroyed on the same night that Alexander the Great was born. Alexander, as king, offered to pay to rebuild the temple, but his offer was denied. Later, after Alexander died, the temple was rebuilt in 323 BCE.

src: 最早為人所知的運輸是走路，隨著 Homo Erectus（亦即直立人）的出現，人類在兩百萬年前開始直立行走。 他們的演化前輩南方古猿並不習慣直立行走。 在 420 至 390 萬年前的南方古猿化石中發現了雙足運動的特性，儘管查德人猿可能早在七百萬年前就已用雙足行走。
mt: The earliest known mode of transportation was walking, which was developed by Homo Erectus (also known as upright man) about two hundred thousand years ago. Their predecessor, the South African Ape, was not accustomed to walking upright. The characteristic of bipedalism was found in the fossil of the South African Ape dating back to 420 to 390 thousand years ago, although the Chadian Ape may have been walking upright as early as seven hundred thousand years ago.
ref: The first known transportation was walking, humans began walking upright two million years ago with the emergence of Homo Erectus (meaning upright man). Their predecessors, the Australopithecus did not walk upright as habitually. Bipedal specializations are found in Australopithecus fossils from 4.2-3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus may have walked on two legs as early as seven million years ago.

src: 使用船運送貨物，是目前為止跨海移動大量人員和貨物的最有效率方式。 傳統上，海軍的任務是確保國家可安穩地轉移人民和貨物，同時干擾敵國轉移人員和貨物的作業。 其中近代最值得關注的例子之一，是第二次世界大戰的北大西洋戰役。美國人試圖將人員和物資運送到大西洋的另外一邊，以幫助英國。 於此同時，德國海軍則試圖阻斷運輸（主要使用 U 型潛艇）。 如果盟軍戰敗，德國可能會像征服歐洲其他地區一樣征服英國。
mt: Moving people and goods by ship is currently the most efficient way to move large numbers of people and goods across the sea. Traditionally, the navy's mission is to ensure that a nation can move its people and goods safely, while interfering with the enemy's movement of people and goods. One of the most notable examples of this in modern times is the Battle of the Atlantic in World War II. The Americans were trying to move people and supplies across the Atlantic to help the British. At the same time, the German navy was trying to block the transport (mainly using U-boats). If the Allies had lost, Germany might have conquered Britain the same way it conquered other parts of Europe.
ref: Using ships to transport goods is by far the most efficient way to move large amounts of people and goods across oceans. The job of navies has traditionally been to ensure that your country maintains the ability to move your people and goods, while at the same time, interfering with your enemy's ability to move his people and goods. One of the most noteworthy recent examples of this was the North Atlantic campaign of WWII. The Americans were trying to move men and materials across the Atlantic Ocean to help Britain. At the same time, the German navy, using mainly U-boats, was trying to stop this traffic. Had the Allies failed, Germany probably would have been able to conquer Britain as it had the rest of Europe.

src: 幅條輪的發明讓亞述人的馬車更輕、更快，且更能跑贏士兵與其他馬車。 致命的十字弓所射出的箭可穿透敵軍身上的盔甲。約在西元前 1 千年，亞述人導入了史上第一支騎兵部隊。 騎兵是指一騎著馬作戰的軍隊。當時尚未發明馬鞍，因此亞述騎兵是騎在毫無裝備的馬背上作戰。
mt: The invention of the chariot allowed Assyrian chariots to be lighter, faster, and able to outrun both soldiers and other chariots. The deadly crossbow bolts could pierce through the armor of the enemy. Around 1000 BC, the Assyrians introduced the world's first cavalry unit. Cavalry is a military unit that fights on horseback. At the time, saddles had not yet been invented, so Assyrian cavalry fought on bareback.
ref: The invention of spoke wheels made Assyrian chariots lighter, faster, and better prepared to outrun soldiers and other chariots. Arrows from their deadly crossbows could penetrate the armor of rival soldiers. About 1000 B.C., the Assyrians introduced the first cavalry. A cavalry is an army that fights on horseback. The saddle had not yet been invented, so the Assyrian cavalry fought on the bare backs of their horses.

src: 巴比倫人為每位神建造一座主要的神廟，那些神廟被視為神的家。 人們會準備祭品獻給神，祭司則會透過儀式與節慶，努力滿足神的需求。 每座神廟都有一個開闊的神廟中庭，接著是一間只有祭司才能進入的內部聖殿。 有些廟宇當中還蓋了金字塔型的特殊塔樓，稱為塔廟。 塔的頂部是神的特殊聖殿。
mt: The Babylonians built a main temple for each god, which was considered the god's home. People would prepare offerings to give to the gods, and priests would try to satisfy the gods' needs through rituals and celebrations. Each temple had an open courtyard in front of it, followed by an inner sanctuary that only priests could enter. Some temples also had special tower-like structures called ziggurats, with the top of the tower being the god's special sanctuary.
ref: The Babylonians built each of their gods a primary temple that was considered the home of the god. People would bring sacrifices to the gods and the priests would try to attend to the needs of the gods through ceremonies and festivals. Each temple had an open temple courtyard and then an inner sanctuary that only the priests could enter. Sometimes special pyramid shaped towers, called ziggurats, were built to be a part of the temples. The top of the tower was special sanctuary for the god.

src: 沒錯！有時也被暱稱「圖坦王」或「少年法老」的圖坦卡門，是現代最著名的古埃及法老之一。 有趣的是，他在古代並不是多重要的人士，也沒有被記錄在大多數古代國王的名單上。 然而，他的墳墓在 1922 年被發現了，這使他成為名人。過去的許多墳墓都曾被盜過，但這座墳墓卻絲毫未被打擾。 大多數和圖坦卡門一起下葬的物件都保存良好，包含用貴金屬與稀有寶石製作的上千個工藝品。
mt: Yes! He is sometimes called Tutankhamun or the Boy King. He is one of the most famous ancient Egyptian pharaohs. It is interesting that he was not an important person in ancient times and was not listed in most lists of ancient kings. However, his tomb was discovered in 1922, making him a celebrity. Many tombs had been robbed in the past, but this tomb was untouched. Most of the objects buried with Tutankhamun were well preserved, including thousands of works of art made of precious metals and rare gems.
ref: "Yes! King Tutankhamun, sometimes referred to as ""King Tut"" or ""The Boy King"", is one of the most well known ancient Egyptian kings in modern times. Interestingly, he was not considered to be very important in ancient times and was not recorded on most ancient king lists. However, the discovery of his tomb in 1922 made him a celebrity. While many tombs of the past were robbed, this tomb was left virtually undisturbed. Most of the items buried with Tutankhamun have been well preserved, including thousands of artefacts made from precious metals and rare stones."

src: 我們認識許多希臘政治家、科學家和藝術家；此文化中最知名的人物也許是傳奇的失明詩人—荷馬，他創作了希臘兩大傑作：史詩《伊利亞德》和《奧德賽》。 蘇弗克里茲和亞里斯多芬至今依然是備受歡迎的劇作家，他們的劇本被視為最偉大的世界文學作品之一。 另一個有名的希臘人是數學家畢達哥拉斯，主要以直角三角形各邊關係的知名定理為人所知。
mt: We know many Greek politicians, scientists and artists; perhaps the most famous person in this culture is the blind poet Homer, who created the two great epics of Greece: the Iliad and the Odyssey. Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights, whose plays are considered one of the greatest works of world literature. Another famous Greek is the mathematician Pythagoras, known for the famous theorem of the relationship of the sides of a right triangle.
ref: We know many Greek politicians, scientists, and artists. Possibly the most known person of this culture is Homer, the legendary blind poet, who composed two masterpieces of Greek literature: the poems Iliad and Odyssey. Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights and their plays are considered to be among the greatest works of world literature. Another famous Greek is a mathematician Pythagoras, mostly known for his famous theorem about relations of the sides of right triangles.

src: 在中東的溫暖氣候中，房子就沒那麼重要了。 猶太家族生活中大多時刻都是在室外度過。 婦女會在院子裡煮飯；商店不過是一個對著大街的櫃檯。當時的人會用石頭建造房屋。 迦南的土地上並沒有大片森林，所以木材特別昂貴。
mt: In the warm climate of the Middle East, houses were not so important. Jewish families spent most of their time outdoors. Women cooked in the courtyard; shops were just a counter facing the street. People built their houses with stones. There were no large forests in Canaan, so wood was very expensive.
ref: In the warm climate of the Middle East, the house was not so important. Most of the life of the Hebrew family happened in the open air. Women did the cooking in the yard; stores were just open counters looking into the street. Stone was used for building houses. There were no large forests in the land of Canaan, so wood was extremely expensive.

src: 格陵蘭島上人煙稀少。在北歐史詩中，紅髮艾瑞克因謀殺被逐出冰島，當他往更遠的西邊去時，發現了格陵蘭島並為它取了這個名字。 但無論他的發現為何，愛斯基摩部落那時已經居住在那裡了。 儘管每個國家都是「斯堪地納維亞人」，但丹麥、瑞典、挪威和冰島的人民、國王、習俗和歷史之間存在許多差異。
mt: Greenland is sparsely populated. In the Norse sagas, Erik the Red was exiled from Iceland for murder, and when he sailed westward, he discovered Greenland and named it. But whether his discovery was what it was, the Inuit had already lived there. Although each country is "Scandinavian", there are many differences between the people, kings, customs and history of Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Iceland.
ref: Greenland was settled sparsely. In the Norse sagas they say that Erik the Red was exiled from Iceland for murder, and when travelling further west, found Greenland and named it Greenland. But regardless of his discovery, Eskimo tribes were already living there at the time. Though each country was 'Scandinavian', there were many differences between the people, kings, customs and history of Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Iceland.

src: 雖然羅馬人的食物對我們來說多半都不陌生，但他們確實會食用一些怪異或罕見的食物，像是野豬、孔雀、蝸牛，以及一種稱作睡鼠的嚙齒動物。 另一個差別是窮人和女人坐在椅子上吃他們的食物時，富有的男人則喜歡一同參加宴席，並在席間側臥享用他們的大餐。 古羅馬的餐飲並不包含日後幾個世紀從美洲或亞洲傳入歐洲的食物。 比方說，他們沒有玉米、番茄、馬鈴薯或可可，古羅馬人也沒吃過火雞。
mt: Although the Romans' food was mostly familiar to us, they did eat some strange or rare foods, such as wild boar, peacocks, snails, and a rodent called dormice. Another difference was that poor people and women sat on chairs to eat their food, while rich men preferred to recline on couches and enjoy their big meals at banquets. Roman dining did not include the foods that would be introduced to Europe from the Americas or Asia in later centuries. For example, they did not eat corn, tomatoes, potatoes, or cocoa, and the Romans did not eat turkey.
ref: While most of their food would be familiar to us, Romans did have their share of strange or unusual feast items, including wild boar, peacock, snails, and a type of rodent called a dormouse Another difference was that while the poor people and the woman ate their food while sitting in chairs, the rich men liked to have banquets together where they would lounge on their sides while they ate their meals. Ancient Roman meals couldn't have included foods that came to Europe from America or from Asia in later centuries. For instance, they didn't have corn, nor tomatoes, nor potatoes, nor cocoa, and no ancient Roman ever tasted a turkey.

src: 文明是由一群數量顯著且以協作方式生活與工作的群眾（亦即社會）所共享的獨特文化。 「文明」這個詞來自拉丁文的「civilis」，意思是「公民的」。它與拉丁文中的「civis」和「civitas」有關，意思分別是「公民」和「城市或城邦」，這在某方面來說也定義了社會的規模。 城邦是國家的前身，文明文化意指傳承數個世代的知識、綿延不斷的文化足跡與普遍的傳播。 規模較小的文化往往不留歷史痕跡便消失殆盡，無法被認定為正統文明。
mt: Civilization is a shared, unique culture of a significant number of people living and working together in a cooperative way (i.e. a society). The word “civilization” comes from the Latin “civilis”, meaning “of a citizen”. It is related to the Latin words “civis” and “civitas”, meaning “citizen” and “city or city-state”, which in some ways also defines the scale of a society. The city-state is the precursor of the nation, and the term “civilization” refers to the transmission of knowledge over several generations, the continuous cultural footprint, and the general dissemination. Smaller cultures often disappear without a trace and cannot be considered a proper civilization.
ref: A civilization is a singular culture shared by a significant large group of people who live and work co-operatively, a society. The word civilization comes from the Latin civilis, meaning civil, related to the Latin civis, meaning citizen, and civitas, meaning city or city-state, and that also somehow defines the size of the society. City-states are the precursors of nations. A civilizational culture implies the passing on of knowledge across several generations, a lingering cultural footprint and fair dissemination. Minor cultures often vanish without leaving relevant historic evidence and fail to be recognized as proper civilizations.

src: 杜克耶堡是位於帕羅區北方（Phondey 村內）的一個堡壘與佛寺廢墟。 據說在 1649 年，活佛夏仲阿旺朗傑為了紀念他對抗西藏蒙古軍隊的勝利，而興建了該碉堡。 1951 年，一場大火使得杜克耶古堡只遺下了一部份的文物，像夏巴尊王的畫像。 大火過後，堡壘倖存且受到保護，仍是不丹最令人驚嘆的景點之一。
mt: Dukye Dzong is a ruined fortress and monastery in the north of Paro district (inside Phondey village). It is said that in 1649, the 4th Desi Tenzin Rabgay built the Dukye Dzong to commemorate his victory over the Tibetan Mongol army. In 1951, a fire destroyed most of the Dukye Dzong’s artifacts, including the image of the Shabdrung. The Dukye Dzong survived the fire and is still one of Bhutan’s most impressive sights.
ref: The Drukgyal Dzong is a ruined fortress and Buddhist monastery in the upper part of the Paro District (in Phondey Village). It is said that in 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel created the fortress to commemorate his victory against the Tibetan-Mongol forces. In 1951, a fire caused for only some of the relics of the Drukgyal Dzong to remain, such as the image of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. After the fire, the fortress was preserved and protected, remaining to be one of Bhutan's most sensational attractions.

In 1951, a fire destroyed most of the Dukye Dzong’s artifacts, including the image of the Shabdrung. The Dukye Dzong survived the fire and is still one of Bhutan’s most impressive sights.
ref: The Drukgyal Dzong is a ruined fortress and Buddhist monastery in the upper part of the Paro District (in Phondey Village). It is said that in 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel created the fortress to commemorate his victory against the Tibetan-Mongol forces. In 1951, a fire caused for only some of the relics of the Drukgyal Dzong to remain, such as the image of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. After the fire, the fortress was preserved and protected, remaining to be one of Bhutan's most sensational attractions.

src: 西元 18 世紀中，柬埔寨被夾在兩個強大鄰國間，即泰國和越南。 泰國人在 18 世紀多次侵略柬埔寨，並在 1772 年摧毀金邊。 在 18 世紀最後幾年，越南人也入侵了柬埔寨。
mt: 18th century, Cambodia was sandwiched between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. Thais invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century and destroyed Phnom Penh in 1772. In the last few years of the 18th century, the Vietnamese also invaded Cambodia.
ref: During the 18th century Cambodia found itself squeezed between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. The Thais invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century and in 1772 they destroyed Phnom Phen. In the last years of the 18th century the Vietnamese also invaded Cambodia.

src: 臺灣的歷史開端可以追溯到 15 世紀，當時的歐洲水手在經過時把這座島的名字記錄為福爾摩沙，意思是美麗的島嶼。 1624 年，荷蘭東印度公司在臺灣西南部建立一處基地，開啟了原住民穀物生產方式的轉型，並雇用中國勞工在該公司的水稻及甘蔗田裡工作。 1683 年，清朝（1644-1912 年）政府以武力掌控了臺灣西部及北部沿海地區，並於 1885 年宣布臺灣是清朝的一省。 1895 年，清朝政府在甲午戰爭（1894-1895 年）戰敗後簽下了《馬關條約》，將臺灣主權割讓給日本。日本從此開始統治臺灣，直到 1945 年為止。
mt: 15th century, when European sailors passed by, recorded the name of the island as Formosa, meaning beautiful island. In 1624, the Dutch East India Company established a base in southwestern Taiwan, which led to the transformation of the indigenous grain production methods and hired Chinese workers to work in the company's rice and sugar cane fields. In 1683, the Qing government (1644-1912) took control of the western and northern coastal areas of Taiwan by force and declared Taiwan a province of the Qing Empire in 1885. In 1895, the Qing government signed the Treaty of Shimonoseki (1894-1895) after losing the Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895), and ceded Taiwan's sovereignty to Japan. Japan began to govern Taiwan from then until 1945.
ref: Taiwan beginning start way back in 15th century where European sailors passing by record the island’s name as Ilha Formosa, or beautiful island. In 1624,Dutch East India Company establishes a base in southwestern Taiwan, initiating a transformation in aboriginal grain production practices and employing Chinese laborers to work on its rice and sugar plantations. In 1683, Qing dynasty (1644-1912) forces take control of Taiwan’s western and northern coastal areas and declared Taiwan as a province of the Qing Empire in 1885. In 1895, after defeat in the First Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895), the Qing government signs the Treaty of Shimonoseki, by which it cedes sovereignty over Taiwan to Japan, which rules the island until 1945.

src: 這稱為化學的酸鹼度。您可以用紫甘藍汁來作為指示劑。 甘藍汁會根據化學物質的酸鹼度變色。 酸鹼值 (pH) 是根據化學物質中的氫離子含量而定（pH 的 H 就是指氫）。 氫離子是失去電子後的質子（因為氫原子由一個質子和一個電子組成）。
mt: This is called the pH of a chemical. You can use a pH indicator such as red cabbage juice. The juice will change color according to the pH of the chemical. The pH is determined by the concentration of hydrogen ions in the chemical (the H in pH stands for hydrogen). Hydrogen ions are protons that have lost an electron (because hydrogen atoms are made up of one proton and one electron).
ref: This is called a chemical's pH. You can make an indicator using red cabbage juice. The cabbage juice changes color depending on how acidic or basic (alkaline) the chemical is. The pH level is indicated by the amount of Hydrogen (the H in pH) ions in the tested chemical. Hydrogen ions are protons that had their electrons stripped off them (since Hydrogen atoms consist of one proton and one electron).

src: 獅子是最群居性的貓科，生活在名為獅群的大團體中。 獅群裡有一到三隻成年公獅，再加上多達三十隻母獅和幼獅組成。 雌獅通常彼此為近親，是同一大家族中的姐妹和女兒。 獅群的行為和狼群或狗群非常相像，這兩種動物意外地和獅子 (但不包括其他大型貓科) 相似，而且也對牠們的獵物非常狠。
mt: Lions are the most social of cats, living in large groups called prides. Prides consist of one to three adult males, plus related females and their offspring. Females typically live together in prides, which are made up of mothers, daughters, and sisters. Lion behavior is similar to that of wolves and dogs, which are also social carnivores that hunt in packs, and lions are similarly ferocious when hunting their prey.
ref: Lions are the most social cats, living in large groups called prides. Prides are made up of one to three related adult males, along with as many as thirty females and cubs. The females are usually closely related to each other, being a large family of sisters and daughters. Lion prides act much like packs of wolves or dogs, animals surprisingly similar to lions (but not other big cats) in behavior, and also very deadly to their prey.

src: 位於牠們之下的是種類較多的中型貓科動物，主要以兔子、羚羊和鹿等中型獵物為食。 最後許多小型貓（偶有家貓）也會捕食為數眾多的小型獵物，包括昆蟲、齧齒類動物、蜥蜴和鳥類。 成功的秘訣在於利基的觀念，也就是每一隻貓要做的工作都是獨特的，如此一來牠們就不會彼此競爭。
mt: Below them are the more numerous medium-sized cats, which feed mainly on medium-sized prey such as rabbits, antelopes, and deer. Finally, many small cats (including domestic cats) also feed on the abundant small prey, including insects, rodents, lizards, and birds. The key to success is niche specialization, meaning that each cat has a unique job to do, so they don't compete with each other.
ref: Under them are more medium sized cats that eat medium sized prey ranging from rabbits to antelopes and deer. Finally, there are many small cats (including loose pet cats) that eat the far more numerous small prey like insects, rodents, lizards, and birds. The secret to their success is the concept of the niche, a special job each cat holds that keeps it from competing with others.

src: 美洲豹貓喜歡吃小型動物，牠們會獵捕猴子、蛇和齧齒動物，可以的話也會獵捕鳥類。美洲豹貓的獵物幾乎都比牠們的體型小很多。 科學家認為美洲豹貓憑靠嗅覺跟蹤和尋找獵物，用嗅聞的方式找出獵物出沒的地點。 牠們在夜晚擁有良好的夜視能力，還可以靜悄悄地移動。虎貓狩獵的方式是與周圍環境融為一體，然後再撲向獵物。
mt: Jaguars are carnivores that eat small animals, including monkeys, snakes, and rodents, and birds when they can. Their prey is usually much smaller than they are. Scientists believe jaguars track and find prey by scent, using their sense of smell to locate where prey is. They have good night vision and can move quietly at night. Jaguars hunt by blending into their environment and then pouncing on prey.
ref: Ocelots like to eat small animals. They will catch monkeys, snakes, rodents and birds if they can. Almost all of the animals that the ocelot hunts are far smaller than it is. Scientists think that ocelots follow and find animals to eat (prey) by smell, sniffing for where they've been on the ground. They can see very well in the dark with night vision, and move very stealthily, too. Ocelots hunt their prey by blending in with their surroundings then pouncing on their prey.

src: 老虎是全方面的運動員，能攀爬（雖然不太專精）﹑游泳﹑遠距離跳躍並擁有超過一個強壯人類五倍的拉力。 老虎和獅子、花豹及美洲豹屬於同一類（豹屬）。只有這四種貓科動物有吼嘯的能力。 老虎的吼嘯不像獅子全然是嗓音的吼嘯，而比較像是一句混亂、喊叫的話語。
mt: Tigers are all-round athletes, able to climb (though not particularly well), swim, jump long distances, and possess a pull strength over five times that of a strong human. Tigers, lions, leopards, and jaguars are all members of the same family (Felidae). Only these four cat species have the ability to roar. A tiger's roar is not like a lion's full-throated roar, but more like a jumbled, shouted sentence.
ref: A well rounded athlete, the tiger can climb (though not well), swim, leap great distances and pull with five times the force of a strong human. The tiger is in the same group (Genus Panthera) as lions, leopards, and jaguars. These four cats are the only ones who can roar. The tiger's roar is not like the full-voiced roar of a lion, but more like a sentence of snarly, shouted words.

src: 細胞是生命 (物) 有機體最小的構造單位和功能單位。 細胞一詞來自拉丁文的 cella，意指小空間。 如果你在顯微鏡下觀察生物，你會看到生物是由小方塊或小圓球組成。 英國生物學家羅伯‧虎克透過顯微鏡觀察到軟木塞中的小方塊。 它們看起來像一個個房間。他是首位觀察到死亡細胞的人。
mt: Cells are the smallest units of life and the basic building blocks of all living things. The word cell comes from the Latin cella, meaning small room. If you look at a living thing under a microscope, you will see that it is made up of small cubes or spheres. Robert Hooke was the first person to observe dead cells. He looked at the cells of a piece of cork under a microscope. They looked like little rooms.
ref: A cell is the smallest structural and functional unit of a living (things) organism. Cell comes from the Latin word cella which means small room. If you look at living things under a microscope, you will see that they are made of small squares or balls. Robert Hooke, a biologist from England, saw small squares in cork with a microscope. They looked like rooms. He was the first person to observe dead cells

src: 動物由眾多細胞構成。牠們吃東西並在體內消化。多數動物都能移動。 只有動物有大腦（然而甚至不是所有動物都有；例如水母就沒有大腦）。 地球各處均能發現動物。牠們在地上挖洞、在海裡游泳、在空中飛翔。
mt: Animals are made up of many cells. They eat and digest food inside their bodies. Most animals can move. Only animals have brains (although not all animals do; for example, jellyfish don't have brains). Animals can be found all over the Earth. They dig holes in the ground, swim in the sea, and fly in the air.
ref: Animals are made of many cells. They eat things and digest them inside. Most animals can move. Only animals have brains (though not even all animals do; jellyfish, for example, do not have brains). Animals are found all over the earth. They dig in the ground, swim in the oceans, and fly in the sky.

src: 植物製造人類吸入的氧氣，並吸收人類呼出的二氧化碳。 植物透過光合作用從陽光中獲取養分。植物同時也能提供遮蔽。 我們用植物蓋房子、做衣服，我們所吃的大部份食物也是植物；如果沒有植物的話，動物將無法生存。
mt: Plants manufacture the oxygen we breathe and absorb the carbon dioxide we exhale. Plants obtain their nutrients from sunlight through photosynthesis. Plants also provide shade. We use plants to build houses, make clothes, and we eat most of our food from plants; without plants, animals would not survive.
ref: Plants make oxygen which humans breathe, and they take in carbon-dioxide which humans exhale (that is, breathe out). Plants make their food from the sun by photosynthesis. src: 當一小群生物（一個小族群）與他們所來自的主要族群分開時（例如越過山脈或河流，或是移居到新到島嶼，以致無法輕易返回），他們通常會發現自己身處的環境與以往不同。 這個新環境有不同的資源和不同的競爭者，因此新人口需要不同的特質或改變，才能具備比過去更強大的競爭力。 原本的人口則完全沒有改變，因此仍需要跟以前一樣的適應功能。 隨著時間過去，新生人口開始適應新環境，他們的外表便與其他人越來越不同。 最終，經過數千年，或甚至數百萬年，這兩個群體看起來將非常不同，以至於無法稱為相同物種。 這個過程稱為種化，表示新物種產生。種化是演化過程中無法避免的後果，也是很重要的一環。
mt: When a small group of organisms (a small population) becomes separated from the main population (for example, by crossing a mountain or river, or by moving to a new island, so that it is difficult to return), they will often find themselves in a new environment that is different from the one they are used to. This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so the new population needs different traits or changes to have a stronger competitive advantage than the original population. The original population remains unchanged, so it still needs the same adaptive features. As time passes, the new population begins to adapt to the new environment, and they look different from other people. Finally, after thousands of years, or even millions of years, these two groups will look so different that they cannot be considered the same species. This process is called speciation, meaning that a new species is produced. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence of the evolutionary process and is an important part of it.
ref: When a small group of living things (a small population) gets separated from the main population that they came from (like if they move over a mountain range or a river, or if they move to a new island so that they can't easily move back) they will often find themselves in a different environment than they were in before. This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so the new population will need different features or adaptations to be a strong competitor than what they had needed before. The original population hasn't changed at all, they still need the same adaptations as before. Over time, as the new population begins to adapt to their new environment, they start to look less and less like the other population. Eventually, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they can't be called the same species. We call this process speciation, which just means the formation of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

mt: The main organ of the circulatory system is the heart, which pumps blood to all parts of the body. Blood leaves the heart through vessels called arteries and returns to the heart through vessels called veins. The smallest blood vessels are called capillaries.

src: 昆蟲是最早在空中飛翔的動物。它們的飛行能力使它們能更輕易地躲開天敵，並更有效地找到食物和配偶。 大部分的昆蟲都有把翅膀沿著身體摺疊起來之優勢。 這使牠們有更多可鑽入的小地方來躲避捕食者。 現今，無法收起翅膀的昆蟲只有蜻蜓與蜉蝣。
mt: Insects are the earliest animals to fly in the air. Their flying ability allows them to escape predators more easily and find food and mates more effectively. Most insects have the advantage of folding their wings along their body. This allows them to have more places to hide from predators. Today, insects that cannot fold their wings are only dragonflies and mayflies.
ref: Insects were the first animals to take to the air. Their ability to fly helped them evade enemies more easily and find food and mates more efficiently. Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings back along the body. This gives them a wider range of small places to hide from predators. Today, the only insects that cannot fold back their wings are dragon flies and mayflies.

src: 現今，許多古生物學家相信有一群恐龍存活至現代，也就是我們所稱的鳥類。 因為牠們長著羽毛且能夠飛翔，很多人不認為牠們是恐龍的一種。 但鳥類與恐龍仍有許多相似之處。 牠們的腳上有鱗片和爪子、會下蛋，而且會像暴龍一樣用兩隻後腳行走。
mt: Today, many paleontologists believe that a group of dinosaurs survived into modern times, which is what we call birds. Because they have feathers and can fly, many people do not consider them to be a type of dinosaur. But birds and dinosaurs have many similarities. They have scales and claws on their feet, lay eggs, and walk on two legs like a Tyrannosaurus rex.
ref: Many paleontologists today believe that one group of dinosaurs survived and is alive today. We call them birds. Many people don't think about them as dinosaurs because they have feathers and can fly. But there are a lot of things about birds that still look like a dinosaur. They have feet with scales and claws, they lay eggs, and they walk on their two back legs like a T-Rex.

src: 三角龍的牙齒不僅能咬碎樹葉，甚至連堅硬的樹枝和樹根也能搞定。 部分科學家認為三角龍會吃蘇鐵屬植物，即白堊紀常見的一種植物。 這些植物看起來像是小型的棕櫚樹，樹冠有銳利尖刺形葉片。 三角龍會在食用樹幹之前，用牠強而有力的喙扯下樹葉。 其他科學家主張這些植物有劇毒，因此恐龍不可能吃下它們，雖然現在樹懶和其他如鸚鵡（恐龍的後代）等動物可以吃有毒的葉子或果實。
mt: 3-horned dinosaurs had teeth that could bite through leaves, and even hard branches and roots. Some scientists think the dinosaurs ate cycads, a common plant of the age. These plants look like small palms, with sharp-pointed leaflets. The dinosaurs would tear off the leaves before eating the trunk with their strong beaks. Other scientists argue that the plants were poisonous, so the dinosaurs could not eat them, although now tree sloths and other animals like parrots (descendants of dinosaurs) can eat poisonous leaves or fruit.
ref: A triceratops' teeth would have been able to crush not only leaves but even very tough branches and roots. Some scientists think Triceratops ate cycads, which are a type of plant that was common in the Cretaceous. These plants look like a small palm tree with a crown of sharp, spiky leaves. A Triceratops could have used its strong beak to strip off the leaves before eating the trunk. Other scientists argue that these plants are very poisonous so it is unlikely that any dinosaur ate them, even though today the sloth and other animals like the parrot (a descendant of the dinosaurs) can eat poisonous leaves or fruit.

src: 盧森堡的歷史悠久，但 1839 年後才獨立 。 現今，比利時的部分地區在過去曾是盧森堡的一部分，但在 1830 年代的比利時革命之後變成比利時。 盧森堡一直試圖保持中立國的立場，但在第一次和第二次世界大戰時皆被德國佔領。 1957 年，盧森堡成為了如今被稱為歐洲聯盟的組織的創始成員之一。
mt: Luxembourg has a long history, but was independent only after 1839.  Parts of what is now Belgium were once part of Luxembourg, but became part of Belgium after the Belgian Revolution of the 1830s.  Luxembourg has always tried to maintain a neutral position, but was occupied by Germany during both World War I and World War II.  In 1957, Luxembourg was one of the founding members of the organization now known as the European Union.
ref: Luxembourg has a long history but its independence dates from 1839. Present-day parts of Belgium were part of Luxembourg in the past but became Belgian after the 1830s Belgian Revolution. Luxembourg has always tried to remain a neutral country but it was occupied in both World War I and World War II by Germany. In 1957 Luxembourg became a founding member of the organization which is today known as the European Union.

src: 歐洲土耳其 (位於巴爾幹半島的東色雷斯，或稱魯米利亞) 占其國家面積 3%。 土耳其的領土長 1,600 多公里（1,000 英里），寬 800 公里（500 英里），大致上呈現一個矩形形狀。 土耳其的面積，連同湖泊在內，占 783,562 平方公里（300,948 平方英里），其中 755,688 平方公里（291,773 平方英里）在亞洲西南部，23,764 平方公里（9,174 平方英里）在歐洲。 土耳其的面積使它成為世界第 37 大的國家，與法國本土加上英國面積差不多大小。 土耳其三面環海：西邊的愛琴海﹑北邊的黑海以及南邊的地中海。
mt: 3% of Turkey is in Europe (in the eastern part of the Balkan Peninsula, or Rumelia). Turkey's territory is about 1,600 km (1,000 mi) long and 800 km (500 mi) wide, and is roughly rectangular in shape. Turkey's area, including lakes, is 783,562 km² (300,948 sq mi), of which 755,688 km² (291,773 sq mi) is in southwestern Asia and 23,764 km² (9,174 sq mi) in Europe. Turkey's area makes it the world's 37th largest country, about the size of France plus the United Kingdom. Turkey is surrounded by sea on three sides: the Aegean Sea to the west, the Black Sea to the north, and the Mediterranean Sea to the south.
ref: European Turkey (eastern Thrace or Rumelia in the Balkan peninsula) includes 3% of the country. The territory of Turkey is more than 1,600 kilometres (1,000 mi) long and 800 km (500 mi) wide, with a roughly rectangular shape. Turkey's area, including lakes, occupies 783,562 square kilometres (300,948 sq mi), of which 755,688 square kilometres (291,773 sq mi) are in south west Asia and 23,764 square kilometres (9,174 sq mi) in Europe. src: 梵蒂岡的人口為八百人左右，是全世界最小的獨立國家，也是人口最少的國家。 梵蒂岡的法律和官方文書都使用義大利文。 義大利語也是該國大部分工作人口平常使用的語言，拉丁語則多半在宗教儀式中使用。 梵蒂岡的所有公民都是羅馬天主教徒。
mt: Vatican City has a population of about 800, making it the smallest and least populous country in the world. Latin is used in religious ceremonies.  All citizens of the Vatican City are Roman Catholics.
ref: Vatican City's population is around 800. It is the smallest independent country in the world and the country with the lowest population. Vatican City uses Italian in its legislation and official communications. Italian is also the everyday language used by most of those who work in the state while Latin is often used in religious ceremonies. All citizens of Vatican City are Roman Catholic.

mt: Vatican City has a population of about 800, making it the smallest and least populous country in the world.  Italian is the official language of the Vatican City, and is used in most of the country's official documents.  Italian is also the language most commonly used by the country's workforce.  Latin is used in religious ceremonies.  All citizens of the Vatican City are Roman Catholics.
ref: Vatican City's population is around 800. It is the smallest independent country in the world and the country with the lowest population. Vatican City uses Italian in its legislation and official communications. Italian is also the everyday language used by most of those who work in the state while Latin is often used in religious ceremonies. All citizens of Vatican City are Roman Catholic.

src: 現在都用電腦來修改照片和影片。 我們可以用電腦做出精緻複雜的動畫，這種動畫越來越常出現在電視與電影上。 音樂錄製的方式，通常是以精密的電腦處理並進行混音。
mt: Now we use computers to edit photos and videos. We can use computers to make sophisticated and complex animations, and these animations are becoming more common in television and movies. The way music is recorded is usually by precise computer processing and mixing.
ref: Computers today are used to manipulate pictures and videos. Sophisticated animations can be constructed on computers, and this kind of animation is increasingly being used in television and films. Music is often recorded using sophisticated computers to process and mix sounds together.

src: 哈拉帕城和摩亨佐-達羅城的每座房屋裡幾乎都有抽水馬桶，並與一個精密的污水處理系統相連。 在希臘克里特島和聖托里尼的米諾斯諸城中，人們在房子底下發現了下水道系統的遺跡。 在古埃及、波斯和中國也有廁所。羅馬文明中，廁所有時是男女混浴公共澡堂的一部份。
mt: In the cities of Harappa and Mohenjo-daro, almost every house had a flush toilet connected to a sophisticated sewage system. In the Minoan cities of Crete and Santorini, archaeologists have found the remains of a sewer system under the houses. There were toilets in ancient Egypt, Persia, and China. In the Roman world, the latrine was part of a public bathhouse where men and women bathed together.
ref: The cities of Harappa and Mohenjo-daro had a flush toilet in almost every house, attached to a sophisticated sewage system. Remains of sewage systems have been found in the houses of the Minoan cities of Crete and Santorini in Greece. There were also toilets in ancient Egypt, Persia and China. In Roman civilization, toilets were sometimes part of public bath houses where men and women were together in mixed company.

src: 現代溜冰鞋的冰刀有雙重刀刃，刀刃間有一處凹陷。雙重刀刃即使在傾斜時，也能更有效地抓住冰面。 由於冰刀底部略有弧度，當冰刀往某側傾斜時，其接觸冰面的邊緣亦呈彎曲。 這會使溜冰者轉向。如果溜冰鞋右傾，溜冰者會向右轉，如果左傾就會向左轉。
mt: Modern ice skates have double blades, with a groove between the blades. The double blades can grab the ice more effectively even when tilted. Because the bottom of the blade is slightly curved, when the blade is tilted to one side, the edge that touches the ice is also curved. This will cause the skater to turn. If the skate is tilted to the right, the skater will turn to the right, and if tilted to the left, the skater will turn to the left.
ref: The blade on a modern ice skate has a double edge with a concave hollow between them. The two edges allow for a better grasp of the ice, even when tilted. Because the bottom of the blade is slightly curved, as the blade tilts to one side or the other, the edge which is in contact with the ice also curves. This causes the skater to turn. If the skates tilt to the right, the skater turns right, if the skates tilt to the left, the skater turns left.

src: 若要恢復到之前的能階，它們必須排放從光線中獲得的額外能量。 他們透過發出稱為「光子」的微粒子來完成。 科學家稱此過程為「刺激輻射排放」，因為原子會受到亮光刺激，放射出光子，而光線就是一種輻射。 接下來是原子發射光子的圖片。當然，實際上的光子比圖片中小很多。 光子甚至比構成原子的粒子還小！
mt: To return to the previous energy level, they must release the extra energy they gained from the light. They do this by emitting particles called photons. Scientists call this process "stimulated emission of radiation," because the atoms are stimulated by the light to emit photons, which are a form of radiation. Here is a picture of an atom emitting a photon. Of course, the photon is much smaller than the atom. In fact, it is even smaller than the particles that make up the atom!
ref: "To return to their previous energy level, they must get rid of the extra energy they got from the light. They do this by emitting a tiny particle of light called a ""photon"". Scientists call this process ""stimulated emission of radiation"" because the atoms are stimulated by the bright light, causing the emission of a photon of light, and light is a type of radiation. The next picture shows the atoms emitting photons. Of course, in reality photons are a lot smaller than those in the picture. Photons are even smaller than the stuff that makes up atoms!"

src: 在通電數百小時之後，燈泡中的鎢絲最終會燒壞，燈泡也不再發亮。 這時就需要更換燈泡了。更換燈泡時必須非常小心。 首先，必須關閉燈具開關，或拔掉電源線。 這是因為如果您在燈泡的金屬底座仍有部份插在插座上時，觸碰到插座內部或其金屬底座，則流入燈泡金屬部份插座的電流，會讓您嚴重觸電。
mt: After hundreds of hours of operation, the tungsten filament in the bulb eventually burns out, and the bulb no longer lights up. At this point, the bulb needs to be replaced. When replacing the bulb, you must be very careful. First, you must turn off the lamp switch or pull out the power cord. This is because if you touch the metal base of the bulb that is still partially inserted into the socket, the current flowing into the metal part of the socket will cause you to be seriously electrocuted.
ref: After hundreds of hours of operation the filament in the bulb eventually burns out and the light bulb no longer works. The light bulb then needs replacing. It is necessary to be careful in replacing the light bulb. First, the switch for the light fixture needs to be turned off or the cable disconnected. This is because electricity flowing into the socket where the metallic part of bulb sits can give you a severe electric shock if you touch the inside of the socket or the metal base of the bulb while it is still partly in the socket.

src: 核分裂炸彈的運作原理，是基於將眾多質子和中子融合成一個原子核需要大量能量。 有點像是推著沉重推車上山。再次分裂原子核會接著釋出一部份的該能量。 有些原子的核心不穩定，這表示它們在沒有或很小推力的情形下也容易分裂。
mt: The operation principle of nuclear fission bombs is based on the fact that it takes a lot of energy to fuse many protons and neutrons into one atomic nucleus. It's like pushing a heavy cart up a hill. The subsequent fission of the atomic nucleus will release some of that energy. Some atomic cores are unstable, meaning they are likely to fission even without or with very little pushing.
ref: The fission bomb works on the principle that it takes energy to put together a nucleus with many protons and neutrons. Sort of like rolling a heavy cart up a hill. Splitting the nucleus up again then releases some of that energy. Some atoms have unstable nuclei which means that they tend to break apart with little or no nudging.

src: 打電話給遠在天邊的朋友時，就是透過人造衛星達成的。 太空中的人造衛星接收到訊號，並在瞬間將訊號反射回地球。 人造衛星是用火箭送上太空的。科學家在太空中使用望遠鏡，因為地球的大氣有時會扭曲我們的光和視線。 需要超過 100 英尺高的巨型火箭，才能將衛星或望遠鏡放上太空。
mt: When you call a friend who lives far away, it's through a satellite. Satellites in space receive the signal and reflect it back to Earth in an instant. Satellites are sent into space by rockets. Scientists use telescopes in space because the Earth's atmosphere sometimes distorts our light and vision. It takes a giant rocket over 100 feet high to put a satellite or telescope into space.
ref: When you call someone who is thousands of miles away, you are using a satellite. The satellite in space gets the call and then reflects it back down, almost instantly. The satellite was sent into space by a rocket. Scientists use telescopes in space because the Earth’s atmosphere distorts some of our light and view. It takes a giant rocket over a 100 feet high to put a satellite or telescope in space.

src: 時間就在我們周圍，影響著我們所做的一切，但又很難理解。 數千年來，宗教、哲學與科學學者都在研究時間。 我們是以從未來到現在、再到過去的一連串事件來感知時間。 時間也是我們比對事件持續期間（長度）的方式。 可透過觀察重複的週期性事件來標記自己的時間流逝。週期性事件指的是定期不斷重複發生的事。
mt: Time is all around us, affecting everything we do, but hard to understand. For thousands of years, religion, philosophy, and science scholars have been studying time. We perceive time as a series of events from the future to the present and then to the past. Time is also a way to measure the duration of events. We mark our passage of time by observing recurring periodic events. Periodic events are events that happen repeatedly at regular intervals.
ref: Time is something that is all around us, and affects everything we do, yet is difficult to understand. Time has been studied by religious, philosophical, and scientific scholars for thousands of years. We experience time as a series of events passing from the future through the present to the past. Time is also how we compare the duration (length) of events. You can mark the passing of time yourself by observing the repetition of a cyclical event. A cyclical event is something that happens again and again regularly.

src: 傳統上，王位繼承人完成學業之後會直接從軍。 然而，查爾斯卻去劍橋的三一學院，修習人類學和考古學，後來又修了歷史，得到了 2:2（二等二級學位）。 查爾斯是首位被授予學位的英國王室成員。
mt: Traditionally, the heir to the throne would go straight into the military after completing his education. However, Charles went to Cambridge's Trinity College to study anthropology and archaeology, and later history, earning a 2:2 (second class, upper division). Charles was the first member of the British royal family to be awarded a degree.
ref: Traditionally, the heir to the throne would go straight into the military after finishing school. However, Charles went to university at Trinity College, Cambridge where he studied Anthropology and Archaeology, and later History, earning a 2:2 (a lower second class degree). Charles was the first member of the British Royal Family to be awarded a degree.

src: 英格蘭在重新征服丹麥區之後，經歷了一段長時間的和平。 然而，埃塞爾雷德 (Ethelred) 在 991 年面臨了一支維京艦隊，其規模是一個世紀前古思倫 (Guthrum) 的艦隊以來最龐大的艦隊。 這支艦隊由奧拉夫·特里格維松率領，這名雄心勃勃的挪威人想要從丹麥手中奪回自己的國家。 歷經一開始的軍事挫敗後，埃塞爾雷德得以和奧拉夫簽訂條款，奧拉夫憑著一連串的成功，重返挪威，試圖奪回他的王國。
mt: After reconquering the Danelaw, England enjoyed a long period of peace. However, in 991, Ethelred faced a Viking fleet that was the largest in a century since Guthrum's fleet. The fleet was led by Olaf Tryggvason, a Norwegian who was ambitious to take back his country from the Danes. After initial military setbacks, Ethelred was able to negotiate a treaty with Olaf, who returned to Norway, trying to take back his kingdom.
ref: England had experienced a long period of peace after the reconquest of the Danelaw. However in 991 Ethelred was faced with a Viking fleet larger than any since Guthrum's a century earlier. This fleet was led by Olaf Trygvasson, a Norwegian with ambitions to reclaim his country from Danish domination. After initial military setbacks, Ethelred was able to agree to terms with Olaf, who returned to Norway to try to gain his kingdom with mixed success.

src: "15 世紀左右，愛沙尼亞北部深受德國文化影響。 有些德國修士想讓本地人民更接近上帝，因此發明了愛沙尼亞文字。 ""它源自於德語字母，並增加了一個 ""Õ/õ"" 字符。"""" 隨著時間的推移，許多從德語借來的詞也融在一起。這是啟蒙的開端。"
mt: "Around the 15th century, the northern part of Estonia was heavily influenced by German culture. Some German monks wanted to bring the local people closer to God, so they invented the Estonian alphabet. "It was based on the German alphabet and added an ""Õ/õ"" character."" Over time, many words borrowed from German were also assimilated. This was the beginning of enlightenment."
ref: "Around the 15th century, northern Estonia was under great cultural influence of Germany. Some German monks wanted to bring God closer to the native people, so they invented the Estonian literal language. It was based on the German alphabet and one character ""Õ/õ"" was added. As time passed, many words that were borrowed from German coalesced. This was the beginning of enlightenment."

src: 對於說印地語的人數有許多不同的估計；印地語估計是世界上使用人口第二至第四大的語言。 持母語者的數量，會根據是否算入近似方言的使用者數量而改變。 使用該語言的人口，估計約有 3.4 億至 5 億人，並且多達 8 億人能了解該語言。 印度語和烏爾都語在語彙上非常相像，但書寫起來很不一樣；在日常的對話中，講這兩種語言的人通常能互相了解。
mt: There are many different estimates of the number of people who speak Hindi; Hindi is estimated to be the second to fourth most spoken language in the world. The number of native speakers varies depending on whether the number of speakers of closely related dialects is included. The number of people who speak the language is estimated to be between 300 and 500 million, and as many as 800 million people understand the language. Hindi and Urdu are very similar in vocabulary but very different in writing; people who speak these languages in everyday conversation usually understand each other.
ref: There are varying estimates for how many people speak Hindi. It is estimated to be between the second and fourth most commonly spoken language in the world. The number of native speakers varies depending on whether or not very closely related dialects are counted. Estimates range from 340 million to 500 million speakers, and as many as 800 million people can understand the language. Hindi and Urdu are similar in vocabulary but different in script; in everyday conversations, speakers of both languages can usually understand each other.

src: 對於說印地語的人數有許多不同的估計；印地語估計是世界上使用人口第二至第四大的語言。 持母語者的數量，會根據是否算入近似方言的使用者數量而改變。 使用該語言的人口，估計約有 3.4 億至 5 億人，並且多達 8 億人能了解該語言。 印度語和烏爾都語在語彙上非常相像，但書寫起來很不一樣；在日常的對話中，講這兩種語言的人通常能互相了解。
mt: There are many different estimates of the number of people who speak Hindi; Hindi is estimated to be the second to fourth most spoken language in the world. The number of native speakers varies depending on whether the number of speakers of closely related dialects is included. The number of people who speak the language is estimated to be between 300 and 500 million, and as many as 800 million people understand the language. Hindi and Urdu are very similar in vocabulary but very different in writing; people who speak these languages in everyday conversation usually understand each other.
ref: There are varying estimates for how many people speak Hindi. It is estimated to be between the second and fourth most commonly spoken language in the world. The number of native speakers varies depending on whether or not very closely related dialects are counted. Estimates range from 340 million to 500 million speakers, and as many as 800 million people can understand the language. Hindi and Urdu are similar in vocabulary but different in script; in everyday conversations, speakers of both languages can usually understand each other.

src: 諺文是唯一一個在日常使用中特意發明的字母。其字母是在世宗年間（1418-1450 年）於 1444 年所發明。 朝鮮王朝的第四任國王是世宗大王，他是最受景仰的國王之一。 他最初將韓文字母命名為「訓民正音」，意思是「教導人民的正確聲音」。
mt: Hangul is the only alphabet ever to have been invented for everyday use. He originally named the Korean alphabet “Hunminjeongeum,” which means “The Proper Sounds to Teach the People.”
ref: "Hangeul is the only purposely invented alphabet in popular daily use. The alphabet was invented in 1444 during the reign of King Sejong (1418 – 1450). King Sejong was the fourth king of the Joseon Dynasty and is one of the most highly regarded. He originally named the Hangeul alphabet Hunmin Jeongeum, which means ""the correct sounds for the instruction of the people""."

src: 有許多關於梵文起源的理論。其中之一為雅利安人從西方遷徙至印度時帶入了原本使用的語言。 梵語是一種古老語言，歷史可媲美歐洲的拉丁語。 世界上已知最早的書是以梵文撰寫。在完成奧義書後，梵文因階級制度而逐漸消亡。 梵語是一種非常複雜又豐富的語言，也是印度許多種現代語言的來源，好比拉丁語也是法語和西班牙語等歐洲語言之源頭一樣。
mt: There are many theories about the origin of Sanskrit. One of them is that the language was brought by the Aryans from the west when they migrated to India. Sanskrit is an ancient language, as old as Latin in Europe. The oldest known book is written in Sanskrit. After the completion of the Vedas, Sanskrit gradually died out due to the caste system. Sanskrit is a very complex and rich language, and is the source of many modern Indian languages, just as Latin is the source of French and Spanish and other European languages.
ref: There are many theories to how Sanskrit came into existence. One of them is about an Aryan migration from the west into India who brought their language with them. Sanskrit is an ancient language and is comparable to the Latin language spoken in Europe. The earliest known book in the world was written in Sanskrit. After the compilation of Upanishads, Sanskrit just faded due to hierarchy. Sanskrit is a very complex and rich language, which has served to be the source for many modern Indian languages, just like Latin is the source for European languages like French and Spanish.

src: 艾奧的重力有多大 對我有多少影響？如果您站在艾奧的地面上，您的體重會比您在地球上的體重輕。 在地球上體重 200 磅（ 90 公斤）的人，到了木衛一上會變成 36 磅（ 16 公斤）。所以說，地心引力對你的拉力當然比較小。
mt: How much does Io's gravity weigh on me? How much does it affect me? If you stand on Io's surface, your weight will be lighter than your weight on Earth. A person weighing 200 pounds (90 kilograms) on Earth will weigh 36 pounds (16 kilograms) on Io. So the gravitational pull of the Earth is certainly smaller.
ref: How would Io's gravity pull on me? If you stood on the surface of Io, you would weigh less than you do on Earth. A person who weighs 200 pounds (90kg) on Earth would weigh about 36 pounds (16kg) on Io. So the gravity, of course, pulls less on you.

src: 月球表面是由岩石和塵土組成。月球的最外層稱為地殼。 地殼在近端厚約七十公里，在遠端厚約一百公里。 它在月海下較薄，在高原下則較厚。 或許在近端因地殼較薄而有更多月海。此處的岩漿較容易浮到表面。
mt: The moon's surface is made of rock and dust. The moon's outer layer is called the crust. The crust is about 70 kilometers thick near the moon's center and about 100 kilometers thick at the moon's far side. It is thinner under the seas and thicker under the highlands. Perhaps there are more seas near the moon's center because the crust is thinner and the magma is easier to rise to the surface.
ref: The surface of the Moon is made of rocks and dust. The outer layer of the Moon is called the crust. The crust is about 70 km thick on the near side and 100 km thick on the far side. It is thinner under the maria and thicker under the highlands. There may be more maria on the near side because the crust is thinner. It was easier for lava to rise up to the surface.

src: 許多人夢想著有一天，人類能到達另一個星球，探索其他嶄新的世界；有些人對太陽系外的事物感到好奇；有些則相信外星人或其他形式的生命可能存在於另一顆星球之上。 但是，如果這確實發生過，那麼可能很長一段時間內都不會再發生。天體分散得如此之廣，以至於「比鄰」天體就相隔了數兆英里。 或許未來的某一天，你的曾孫會在站在外星人的世界中，好奇自己的祖先是誰？
mt: Many people dream of one day humans reaching another planet, exploring new worlds; some are curious about things outside our solar system; some believe extraterrestrials or other forms of life may exist on another planet. But if this were to happen, it would be a long time before it happened again. Celestial bodies are so far apart that "neighboring" celestial bodies are separated by billions of miles. Perhaps one day your great-grandchild will stand in the world of extraterrestrials, wondering who their ancestors were.
ref: "Many people dream of the day when humans can travel to another star and explore other worlds, some people wonder what's out there some belive that aliens or other life may live on another plant. But, if this ever does happen probably won't happen for a very long time. The stars are so spread out that there are trillions of miles between stars that are ""neighbors"". Maybe one day, your great grandchildren will be standing atop an alien world wondering about their ancient ancestors?"

src: 太陽沒有像地球一樣，可以立於其上的地殼。太陽是由氣體、火和電漿組成的。 離太陽中心越遠，氣體就越稀薄。 我們看見的太陽外層稱為「photosphere」，意即「光球」。
mt: The Sun does not have a solid surface like the Earth. The Sun is made up of gas, fire, and plasma. The farther away from the Sun's center, the more rarefied the gas is. The part of the Sun that we see is called the "photosphere," meaning "light sphere."
ref: "The Sun doesn't have a crust like the Earth that you can stand on. The whole Sun is made out of gases, fire, and plasma. The gas becomes thinner as you go farther from the center of the Sun. The outer-part we see when we look at the Sun is called the photosphere, which means ""ball of light""."

src: 大約三千年後，1610 年義大利天文學家伽利略·伽利萊使用望遠鏡觀察到金星和月亮一樣有圓缺變化。 金星（或月球）之所以有盈虧，是因為僅有面對太陽的那一面被照亮。金星盈虧證實了哥白尼的理論──行星繞著太陽旋轉。 接著在幾年後的 1639 年，一名名為傑雷米亞·霍羅克斯的天文學家觀察到了金星凌日。
mt: 3,000 years later, in 1610, Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei used a telescope to observe that Venus and the moon both had phases. Venus (or the moon) had phases because only the side facing the sun was illuminated. The phases of Venus proved Copernicus's theory that the planets revolved around the sun. A few years later, in 1639, a man named Jeremiah Horrocks observed a transit of Venus.
ref: About three thousand years later, in 1610, Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei used a telescope to observe that Venus has phases, just as the moon does. Phases happen because only the side of Venus (or of the Moon) facing the Sun is lighted. The phases of Venus supported the theory of Copernicus that the planets go around the Sun. Then, a few years later in 1639, an English astronomer named Jeremiah Horrocks observed a transit of Venus.

src: 亞馬遜河是地球上第二長、水量最大的一條河。它的水量是世界第二大河的八倍。 亞馬遜河也是地球上最寬的河流，有些河段能達到六英里寬。 地球上流入海洋的河水中，有整整 20％ 是來自於亞馬遜河。 亞馬遜河主流長 6,387 公里（3,980 英里），匯集了來自數千條小型河流的河水。
mt: The Amazon River is the second longest and largest river on Earth. Its water volume is eight times that of the world's second largest river. The Amazon River is also the widest river on Earth, with some stretches reaching six miles wide. Twenty percent of all the fresh water that flows into the ocean comes from the Amazon River. The main stem of the Amazon River is 3,980 miles long, and collects the waters of thousands of small rivers.
ref: The Amazon River is the second longest and the biggest river on Earth. It carries more than 8 times as much water as the second biggest river. The Amazon is also the widest river on Earth, at times six miles wide. A full 20 percent of the water that pours out of the planet's rivers into the oceans comes from the Amazon. The main Amazon River is 6,387 km (3,980 miles). It collects water from thousands of smaller rivers.
